flow.descriptionCdata:
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.0f2f3bd1-79a1-48a6-ac31-eac9aebfd823.description=
This operation checks whether a string matches another string, using a specific matching rule. The "toMatch" input is the string that is checked for matching the "matchTo" expression. 

Inputs\:
    matchType - The type of match to perform.
Valid values\: Exact Match, Contains, Contains Once, Does Not Contain, Match All Words, Match No Words, Regex (The values are not case sensitive)
Default value\: Exact Match
    toMatch - The string that is checked for matching.
    matchTo - The string to match against.
Example\: If "matchType" is “RegEx”, the "matchTo" input is a regular expression such as\: ^-?\d+(([\.,]\d+)?)+$. 
    ignoreCase - Specifies whether to ignore case when matching or not.
Valid values\: False, True
Default value\: False

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the string "Matches" if the "toMatch" string matches the "matchTo" string. Otherwise, it contains the string "Does Not Match".  

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.7d5febe2-9c3d-48f1-8b17-406d4183b6ce.description=
Service to perform HTTP POST using the Java HTTP Client. This  operation is used to execute an HTTP POST request while sending HTTP POST data in raw form instead of including it in the request itself.

Inputs\:
    url - The URL where to send the HTTP POST request.
    username - The user name used for URL authentication. For NTLM authentication, the required format is 'domain\user'.
    password - The password used for URL authentication.
    authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server.
Valid values\: basic, form, springForm, digest, ntlm, kerberos, anonymous (no authentication).
Default value\: anonymous - authentication not used when executing the request.
    kerberosConfFile - The  path to the Kerberos configuration file. If this input is empty, the "kdc" (Key Distribution Center) and "realm" get their values from the full domain name obtained from the web server URL.
    timeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in  milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "timeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    socketTimeout - The time to wait for data to be retrieved, in milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "socketTimeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls. If you specify a non-Boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    proxy - The proxy server used to access the web site.
    proxyPort - The proxy server port.
Default value\: 8080
    proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy server.
    proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the "proxyUsername" input value.
    encodeURL - Specifies whether to encode the URL. If you specify a non-Boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: false
    file - The file to be posted by this operation using the HTTP POST method. This should be a path to a file/document on the disk.
    string - The message body to be posted by this operation using the HTTP POST method.
    contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body.
Examples\: "text/html", "text/html; charset\=UTF-8", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded".
    characterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP POST request and response.
Default value\: UTF-8
    trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL. A SSL certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: allow_all
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
    keystore - The location of the KeyStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS client authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    keystorePassword - The password associated with the KeyStore file. If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "keystore" is empty, "keystorePassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    trustKeystore - The location of the TrustStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS server authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, "trustPassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    headerNamesList - The list containing the header names to use for the request.
Example\: Accept,Content-Type
    headerValuesList - The list containing the header values to use for the request. 
Example\: text/plain,application/x-www-form-urlencoded
    queryNamesList - The list containing the names of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterName1,parameterName2 
    queryValuesList - The list containing the values of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterValue1,parameterValue2
    delimiter - The delimiter used to separates list elements.
Default value\: ','

Results\: 
    returnCode - This is the primary output. A code used to determine the operation response, specifying whether the operation is successful or not.
    resultText - The raw result of the operation.
    document - The complete document returned by the Http Client Post Raw operation.
    URL - The URL used for the HTTP request.
    pageLoadTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken for the page to load.
    responseTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken before the server responded.
    errorMessage - An informational message that can help determine the cause of error, if an error occurred.
    httpResult - The description of the HTTP response returned by the web server for the request sent by this operation. This result contains the HTTP response status or GENERAL_ERROR if the HTTP request could not be executed.
Example\: SUCCESS, PAGE_NOT_FOUND, UNAUTHORIZED, FORBIDDEN and so on.
    responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by "delimiter".
    status - The HTTP response code.
Example\: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    PAGE_NOT_FOUND - The URL specified to POST from was not found.
    INFORMATIONAL - The POST was not fully processed, the server responded with an informational response.
    REDIRECTION - The specified URL has moved.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1. You can use KeyTool to import a SSL certificate in a KeyStore. For example, to import a certificate in the Java cacerts KeyStore, run\: keytool -import -file c\:/../.cer -alias  -keystore /java/lib/security/cacerts -keystorepass changeit. If the KeyStore does not exist, the command tries to create a new one containing only your certificate.
2. You can use KeyTool to create a certificate chain through the following command\: 
   keytool -genkey -dname "cn\=Mark Jones, ou\=JavaSoft, o\=Sun, c\=US" 
      -alias business -keypass kpi135 -keystore C\:\working\mykeystore 
      -storepass ab987c -validity 180
It creates a certificate chain in a new keystore containing only one certificate.
3. If the value assigned to the "trustAllRoots" input is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, the operation tries to use the default trust store, using the password "changeit". 
4. If the authentication type is Kerberos, you might need to add an SPN (Service Principal Name) for the web server's computer account.  In order to do this, you can use ADUC (Active Directory Users and Computers) with enabled 'Advanced Features'. Go to the web server's computer account (example\: CN\=,CN\=Computers,DC\=domain,DC\=com), open the 'Properties' window and press the 'Attribute Editor' tab. Observe the values of the 'servicePrincipalName' attribute and add your SPN if not present. For example, HTTP/\:port.
5. If you need to specify query parameters when making the request, use the "queryNamesList" and "queryValuesList" inputs. The operation also accepts including query parameters in the URL. For example, http\://hostname\:80/page.asp?parameterName1\=parameterValue1¶meterName2\=parameterValue2. If you specify the same query parameter both through the "queryNamesList" and the "url" inputs, the used value is the one from the "queryValuesList", not the one included in the "url".
6. Apache Tomcat is currently the only supported application server when using form-based authentication.
7. This operation uses chunked transfer encoding, which may cause failures when using HTTP servers and proxies that do not support HTTP/1.1 protocol.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.a1c3e73d-77e2-422d-ab7b-eff0110c144f.description=
This operation waits for the number of seconds specified in the "seconds" input.

Inputs\:
    seconds - The number of seconds to wait.

Results\:
    resultString – This is the primary output. It contains the "completed sleep" message if the operation completed successfully and an error message otherwise. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.a7b4853a-2115-4422-bb9f-cabe86d6cba8.description=Counts from one number to another number. 
Inputs\:
from - The number to start counting at.
to - The number to count to.
incrementBy - The number to increment by while counting. If unspecified this is 1. If you wanted to count 2,4,6,8 this would be 2.
reset - If true, then the counter will restart counting from the beginning.

NOTE\: These values must be between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807

Returns\:
The number that was just counted.

Note\: the primary result is resultString, Result can also be used. result (All lower case) should not be used as it is the response code.

Responses\:
has more - Not yet done counting.
no more - Done counting. This will only be returned once, then counting restarts.
failure - Something went wrong.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.d488f8fe-b04a-4003-8824-2299792c21db.description=
Service to perform HTTP POST using the Java HTTP Client. This  operation is used to execute an HTTP POST request while sending HTTP POST data in raw form instead of including it in the request itself.

Inputs\:
    url - The URL where to send the HTTP POST request.
    username - The user name used for URL authentication. For NTLM authentication, the required format is 'domain\user'.
    password - The password used for URL authentication.
    authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server.
Valid values\: basic, form, springForm, digest, ntlm, kerberos, anonymous (no authentication).
Default value\: anonymous - authentication not used when executing the request.
    kerberosConfFile - The  path to the Kerberos configuration file. If this input is empty, the "kdc" (Key Distribution Center) and "realm" get their values from the full domain name obtained from the web server URL.
    timeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in  milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "timeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    socketTimeout - The time to wait for data to be retrieved, in milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "socketTimeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls. If you specify a non-Boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    proxy - The proxy server used to access the web site.
    proxyPort - The proxy server port.
Default value\: 8080
    proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy server.
    proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the "proxyUsername" input value.
    encodeURL - Specifies whether to encode the URL. If you specify a non-Boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: false
    file - The file to be posted by this operation using the HTTP POST method. This should be a path to a file/document on the disk.
    string - The message body to be posted by this operation using the HTTP POST method.
    contentType - The content type that should be set in the request header, representing the MIME-type of the data in the message body.
Examples\: "text/html", "text/html; charset\=UTF-8", "application/x-www-form-urlencoded".
    characterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP POST request and response.
Default value\: UTF-8
    trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL. A SSL certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: allow_all
Valid values\: strict, browser_compatible, allow_all
    keystore - The location of the KeyStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS client authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    keystorePassword - The password associated with the KeyStore file. If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "keystore" is empty, "keystorePassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    trustKeystore - The location of the TrustStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS server authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default value\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file. If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, "trustPassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    headerNamesList - The list containing the header names to use for the request.
Example\: Accept,Content-Type
    headerValuesList - The list containing the header values to use for the request. 
Example\: text/plain,application/x-www-form-urlencoded
    queryNamesList - The list containing the names of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterName1,parameterName2 
    queryValuesList - The list containing the values of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterValue1,parameterValue2
    delimiter - The delimiter used to separates list elements.
Default value\: ','

Results\: 
    returnCode - This is the primary output. A code used to determine the operation response, specifying whether the operation is successful or not.
    resultText - The raw result of the operation.
    document - The complete document returned by the Http Client Post Raw operation.
    URL - The URL used for the HTTP request.
    pageLoadTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken for the page to load.
    responseTimeInMS - The number of milliseconds taken before the server responded.
    errorMessage - An informational message that can help determine the cause of error, if an error occurred.
    httpResult - The description of the HTTP response returned by the web server for the request sent by this operation. This result contains the HTTP response status or GENERAL_ERROR if the HTTP request could not be executed.
Example\: SUCCESS, PAGE_NOT_FOUND, UNAUTHORIZED, FORBIDDEN and so on.
    responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by "delimiter".
    status - The HTTP response code.
Example\: HTTP/1.1 200 OK

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    PAGE_NOT_FOUND - The URL specified to POST from was not found.
    INFORMATIONAL - The POST was not fully processed, the server responded with an informational response.
    REDIRECTION - The specified URL has moved.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1. You can use KeyTool to import a SSL certificate in a KeyStore. For example, to import a certificate in the Java cacerts KeyStore, run\: keytool -import -file c\:/../.cer -alias  -keystore /java/lib/security/cacerts -keystorepass changeit. If the KeyStore does not exist, the command tries to create a new one containing only your certificate.
2. You can use KeyTool to create a certificate chain through the following command\: 
   keytool -genkey -dname "cn\=Mark Jones, ou\=JavaSoft, o\=Sun, c\=US" 
      -alias business -keypass kpi135 -keystore C\:\working\mykeystore 
      -storepass ab987c -validity 180
It creates a certificate chain in a new keystore containing only one certificate.
3. If the value assigned to the "trustAllRoots" input is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, the operation tries to use the default trust store, using the password "changeit". 
4. If the authentication type is Kerberos, you might need to add an SPN (Service Principal Name) for the web server's computer account.  In order to do this, you can use ADUC (Active Directory Users and Computers) with enabled 'Advanced Features'. Go to the web server's computer account (example\: CN\=,CN\=Computers,DC\=domain,DC\=com), open the 'Properties' window and press the 'Attribute Editor' tab. Observe the values of the 'servicePrincipalName' attribute and add your SPN if not present. For example, HTTP/\:port.
5. If you need to specify query parameters when making the request, use the "queryNamesList" and "queryValuesList" inputs. The operation also accepts including query parameters in the URL. For example, http\://hostname\:80/page.asp?parameterName1\=parameterValue1¶meterName2\=parameterValue2. If you specify the same query parameter both through the "queryNamesList" and the "url" inputs, the used value is the one from the "queryValuesList", not the one included in the "url".
6. Apache Tomcat is currently the only supported application server when using form-based authentication.
7. This operation uses chunked transfer encoding, which may cause failures when using HTTP servers and proxies that do not support HTTP/1.1 protocol.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.dd2ec96c-a1bb-43ad-9d39-20464c748f71.description=
Service to perform HTTP GET using the Java HTTP Client. This operation displays the retrieved data. It is usually used for retrieving data in a text format. This operation is not used for downloading arbitrary, non-text data. For this, use the "Http Client Get to File" operation.

Inputs\:
    url - The URL to retrieve.
    username - The user name used for URL authentication. For NTLM authentication, the required format is "domain\user".
    password - The password used for URL authentication.
    authType - The type of authentication used by this operation when trying to execute the request on the target server.
Valid values\: basic, form, springForm, digest, ntlm, kerberos, anonymous (no authentication).
Default value\: anonymous - authentication not used when executing the request.
    kerberosConfFile - The path to the Kerberos configuration file. If this input is empty, the "kdc" (Key Distribution Center) and "realm" get their values from the full domain name obtained from the web server URL.
    timeout - The time to wait for a connection to be established, in milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "timeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    socketTimeout - The time to wait for data to be retrieved, in milliseconds. 
Valid values\: This input needs a value greater than or equal to zero. A "socketTimeout" value of '0' represents an infinite timeout.
Default value\: 0
    useCookies - Specifies whether to enable cookie tracking or not. Cookies are stored between consecutive calls. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    followRedirects - Specifies whether the 'Get' command automatically follows redirects. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: false
    proxy - The proxy server used to access the web site.
    proxyPort - The proxy server port.
Default value\: 8080
    proxyUsername - The user name used when connecting to the proxy.
    proxyPassword - The proxy server password associated with the "proxyUsername" input value.
    encodeURL - Specifies whether to encode the URL. If you specify a non-boolean value, the default value is used.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: false
    userAgent - The value to use if the 'USER_AGENT' HTTP header has to be overwritten.
    characterSet - The character encoding to be used for the HTTP 'Get' request and response.
Default value\: UTF-8 
    trustAllRoots - Specifies whether to enable weak security over SSL. A SSL certificate is trusted even if no trusted certification authority issued it.
Valid values\: true, false
Default value\: true
    x509HostnameVerifier - Specifies the way the server hostname must match a domain name in the subject's Common Name (CN) or subjectAltName field of the X.509 certificate. The hostname verification system prevents communication with other hosts other than the ones you intended. This is done by checking that the hostname is in the subject alternative name extension of the certificate. This system is designed to ensure that, if an attacker(Man In The Middle) redirects traffic to his machine, the client will not accept the connection. If you set this input to "allow_all", this verification is ignored and you become vulnerable to security attacks. For the value "browser_compatible" the hostname verifier works the same way as Curl and Firefox. The hostname must match either the first CN, or any of the subject-alts. A wildcard can occur in the CN, and in any of the subject-alts. The only difference between "browser_compatible" and "strict" is that a wildcard (such as "*.foo.com") with "browser_compatible" matches all subdomains, including "a.b.foo.com". From the security perspective, to provide protection against possible Man-In-The-Middle attacks, we strongly recommend to use "strict" option.
Default value\: allow_all
Valid values\: strict,browser_compatible,allow_all
    keystore - The location of the KeyStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS client authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    keystorePassword - The password associated with the KeyStore file. If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "keystore" is empty, "keystorePassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    trustKeystore - The location of the TrustStore file - a URL or the local path to it. This input is empty if no HTTPS server authentication is used. The default value will be provided if "trustAllRoots" is "false".
Default\: /java/lib/security/cacerts
    trustPassword - The password associated with the TrustStore file.  If "trustAllRoots" is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, "trustPassword" default will be supplied.
Default value\: changeit
    headerNamesList - The list containing the header names to use for the request.
Example\: Accept,Content-Type
    headerValuesList - The list containing the header values to use for the request. 
Example\: text/plain,application/x-www-form-urlencoded
    queryNamesList - The list containing the names of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterName1,parameterName2 
    queryValuesList - The list containing the values of the query parameters to use for the request. 
Example\: parameterValue1,parameterValue2
    delimiter - The delimiter used to separates list elements.
Default value\: ','

Results\:
    resultText - This is the primary output. The raw result of the operation.
    document - The complete document returned by the Http Client Get operation.
    URL - The URL used for the GET.
    pageLoadTimeInMS - The time it took the page to load, in milliseconds.
    responseTimeInMS - The time it took the server to respond, in milliseconds.
    errorMessage - An informational message that can help determine the cause of error, if an error occurred.
    httpResult - The description of the HTTP response returned by the web server for the request sent by this operation. This result contains the HTTP response status or GENERAL_ERROR if the HTTP request could not be executed.   
Examples\: SUCCESS, PAGE_NOT_FOUND, UNAUTHORIZED, FORBIDDEN and so on.
    responseHeaders - The list containing the headers of the response message, separated by "delimiter".
    status - The HTTP response code.
Example\: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
    urls - The list containing the URLs linked to this page. Each URL is listed once.

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Notes\:
1. You can use KeyTool to import a SSL certificate in a KeyStore. For example, to import a certificate in the Java cacerts KeyStore, run\: keytool -import -file c\:/../.cer -alias  -keystore /java/lib/security/cacerts -keystorepass changeit. If the KeyStore does not exist, the command tries to create a new one containing only your certificate.
2. You can use KeyTool to create a certificate chain through the following command\: 
   keytool -genkey -dname "cn\=Mark Jones, ou\=JavaSoft, o\=Sun, c\=US" 
      -alias business -keypass kpi135 -keystore C\:\working\mykeystore 
      -storepass ab987c -validity 180
This creates a certificate chain in a new KeyStore containing only one certificate. It is useful in SSL client authentication because the KeyManager ignores any certificates not included in a certificate chain.
3. If the value assigned to the "trustAllRoots" input is "false" and "trustKeystore" is empty, the operation tries to use the default trust store, using the password "changeit". 
4. If the authentication type is Kerberos, you might need to add an SPN (Service Principal Name) for the web server's computer account.  In order to do this, you can use ADUC (Active Directory Users and Computers) with enabled 'Advanced Features'. Go to the web server's computer account (example\: CN\=,CN\=Computers,DC\=domain,DC\=com), open the Properties window and press the 'Attribute Editor' tab. Check the values of the 'servicePrincipalName' attribute and add your SPN if not present. For example, HTTP/\:port.
5. If you need to specify the request header fields, use the "headerNamesList" and "headerValuesList" inputs. The operation also accepts hidden inputs whose names begin with "header_", but this is deprecated. You can add multiple headers.  For example, add an input name called "header_Content-Type" with a "text/html" value and/or an input name called "header_Content-Length" with a "348" value.  The operation strips off the "header_" prefix from the input name and then creates the "Content-Type" and/or "Content-Length" header with the value you specified. If you specify the same header through both the "headerNamesList" and the "header_" hidden inputs, the value used is the one from the "headerValuesList" list, and not from the hidden input.
6. If you need to specify query parameters when making the request, use the "queryNamesList" and "queryValuesList" inputs. The operation also accepts including query parameters in the URL. For example, http\://hostname\:80/page.asp?parameterName1\=parameterValue1¶meterName2\=parameterValue2. If you specify the same query parameter both through the "queryNamesList" and the "url" inputs, the used value is the one from the "queryValuesList", not the one included in the "url".
7. Apache Tomcat is currently the only supported application server when using form-based authentication.
dfc6cc41-3111-411a-baf3-f881c08427cb.fde2233f-2011-4cc8-8723-5e5cbcd7f27d.description=
This operation waits for the number of seconds specified in the "seconds" input.

Inputs\:
    seconds - The number of seconds to wait.

Results\:
    resultString – This is the primary output. It contains the "completed sleep" message if the operation completed successfully and an error message otherwise. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.
flow.name: powerOffServerAzure
